channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Russia Strikes Cities Far From Front Lines
item.description: At least three cities in western and central Ukraine were hit. In besieged Mariupol, bodies are now being buried in trenches. President Biden will call for suspending normal trade relations with Russia.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Humanitarian and medical supplies were loaded Thursday onto a train in Lviv, Ukraine, that was bound for the city of Dnipro.

item.title: A Family’s Dash Toward Safety in Ukraine Ends Tragically
item.description: Tetiana Perebyinis and her two children were killed trying to dash to safety, a moment captured by our photographer. Her husband describes their lives, and their final hours.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Serhiy Perebyinis lost his wife, Tetiana, and both of their children to Russian mortar shelling as they tried to flee Irpin, near Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv.

item.title: India Elections: Uttar Pradesh Looks Likely to Stay in B.J.P.’s Hands
item.description: Uttar Pradesh, India’s most populous state, is staying in the Bharatiya Janata Party’s hands, as the party maintains its electoral success despite mounting economic hardship.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh and Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: B.J.P. supporters celebrate victory in Lucknow, the state capital of Uttar Pradesh, on Thursday.

item.title: How Billionaires Are Shaping France’s Presidential Campaign
item.description: In a nation with strict political finance laws, control over the news media has provided an avenue for the very rich to influence elections, this one more than ever.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
item.category: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SA
item.media:description: A campaign rally for Éric Zemmour, a French far-right presidential candidate, last month. He has set the themes of the race with the anti-immigrant and anti-Muslim views he had put forth on television in recent years.

item.title: Harris, in Poland, Seeks to Present United Front Against Russia
item.description: Vice President Kamala Harris visited Warsaw a day after U.S. officials said they were blindsided by Poland’s offer to provide jet fighters to Ukraine. Washington rejected it, fearing it could escalate the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris and President Andrzej Duda of Poland during a news conference on Thursday in Warsaw.

item.title: Australia Asks: How Far Is Too Far in Making China a Campaign Weapon?
item.description: Australia’s conservative government has claimed, without evidence, that the political opposition would cozy up to Beijing. To many, it has crossed a red line.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chinatown in Sydney, Australia. The Chinese diaspora in the country is concerned about the demonization of China ahead of an election.

item.title: U.S. Says North Korea Is Testing a New Intercontinental Missile
item.description: The missile, first displayed in 2020, was tested twice in recent days. While it is unclear whether it can reach the U.S., it poses a new military challenge to President Biden in the midst of the Ukraine war.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: KCNA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: It is not clear whether the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, timed the tests to come at a time of maximum distraction in Washington and fear of a broader war in Europe.

item.title: Burkina Faso Awaits the Verdict in the Sankara Assassination Trial
item.description: Thirty-five years after the killing of President Thomas Sankara of Burkina Faso, his supporters hope for justice. But the full truth about the murder, including any foreign role, is elusive.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Malin Fezehai for The New York Times
item.media:description: The statue commemorating Thomas Sankara in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso.

item.title: An Urgent Mission for Literary Translators: Bringing Ukrainian Voices to the West
item.description: A wartime effort to quickly translate work by Ukrainian novelists, poets and historians is underway — a project as political as it is cultural, authors and translators say.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Valerie Plesch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zenia Tompkins founded an agency dedicated to Ukrainian literature in translation in 2019.

item.title: 4 Falsehoods Russians Are Told About the War
item.description: Russia’s disinformation machine is working in overdrive inside its own borders.
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:description: An apartment building in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Tuesday, that was destroyed after shelling.

item.title: Poland’s Tourism Industry Is Helping Ukrainian Refugees
item.description: As Ukrainians flood into Poland, the travel industry has become part of an effort to supply transportation, accommodations and more to people fleeing the Russian invasion.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeginsu and Magdalena Chodownik

item.title: ISIS Names a New Leader, but Says Little About Him
item.description: The terrorist group announced its new leader as Abu al-Hasan al-Hashimi al-Qurashi, but gave no information about his background or true identity.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A faded flag of the Islamic State in Raqqa, Syria, in 2018.

item.title: Yoon Suk-yeol Wins South Korean Presidency
item.description: As a prosecutor, he went after former presidents. Now voter discontent has helped him take the presidency in the tightest race since 1987.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: South Korea’s newly elected president, Yoon Suk-yeol, celebrating in front of the People Power Party headquarters in Seoul on Thursday.

item.title: An Exiled Theater With a Warning for Europe
item.description: The Belarus Free Theater’s members fled repression at home. The company’s latest show imagines a nightmare future of authoritarian Russian rule.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Jeremie Souteyrat for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rehearsal for “Dogs of Europe,” which opens at the Barbican theater in London on Thursday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Russian forces surround Ukrainian cities.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers standing guard in Maidan Square in Kyiv.

item.title: Biden Will Call for Suspending Normal Trade Relations With Russia
item.description: The move, expected to be joined by the G7 and the European Union, would result in higher tariffs on Russian products being sent to the United States.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Katie Rogers
item.media:description: Shipping containers at a commercial port in Vladivostok, Russia, in October.

item.title: Climate Change’s Threat to the Glorious Redwood, Both Here and Afar
item.description: In 1936, foresters planted California redwoods in Victoria. How long will they grow in peace?
item.dc:creator: Meghan Dansie
item.media:credit: Jade Byrnes for The New York Times
item.media:description: California redwoods in Victoria, Australia.

item.title: Biden Officials Contend With Bioweapons Propaganda From Russia and China
item.description: The Biden administration says the two countries’ promotion of anti-U.S. conspiracy theories might be cover for lethal Russian military operations.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Chinese President Xi Jinping, left, and Russian President Vladimir V. Putin in 2019. The two leaders have grown closer, largely because of a shared desire to undermine American global dominance.

item.title: Russia Batters and Encircles Ukrainian Cities, as Diplomacy Falters
item.description: The first meeting during the war of the two countries’ foreign ministers yielded no cease-fire. The Russian side signaled that its invasion would not stop until Ukraine surrendered.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yelena Lavinska, 22, in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, on Thursday, mourning her fiancé, a Ukrainian soldier who was killed in combat.

item.title: Facing Economic Calamity, Putin Talks of Nationalizing Western Businesses
item.description: With the ruble collapsing, the economy contracting and people abandoning the country, Russia’s leader talks of a Western plot to destroy the country.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A supermarket in Moscow last month. With a plummeting ruble, prices have doubled recently, as Western sanctions bite.

item.title: These Small, Cheap Devices Help Monitor Haiti’s Earthquakes
item.description: When conventional seismometers in Haiti failed before the 2010 quake, less sophisticated devices operated by citizen scientists helped seismic researchers fill in the blanks.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:credit: Valerie Baeriswyl for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cleanup near Camp-Perrin in Haiti in the aftermath of the earthquake that struck last August.

item.title: Thirteen Governors Want the Public Health Emergency Extended Beyond April
item.description: In a letter to the U.S. health secretary, the governors, all Democrats, said they needed more time to prepare for when the emergency expires, taking with it federal resources that state programs depend on.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat and Ada Petriczko
item.media:credit: Cathy Cheney/Portland Business Journal via AP
item.media:description: Oregon Gov. Kate Brown and 12 other governors wrote a letter to Health Secretary Xavier Becerra urging him to extend the country’s public health emergency declaration.

item.title: ‘Inadequate’ Security Led to Deaths of 3 Americans in Kenya Attack, Report Finds
item.description: The inquiry also found shortcomings in the sharing of intelligence before the deadly assault by the Shabab in 2020.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Caroline Brehman/CQ Roll Call, via Associated Press
item.media:description: “We were not as prepared at Manda Bay as we needed to be,” Gen. Stephen J. Townsend, the commander of Africa Command, said at a presentation of the report’s findings at the Pentagon on Thursday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Russia Makes Slow Advances
item.description: Talks in Turkey ended without agreement.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yelena Lavinska, 22, joined by relatives, friends, and comrades, mourned the death of her fiance, Ukrainian soldier, Mikhailo Pristupa, who was shot and killed in combat in Irpin on March 5, during his wake and funeral at the Baikove Cemetery in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: IMF Warns Ukraine-Russia War Will Likely Slow Global Growth
item.description: The economic fallout from Russia’s invasion will depend on the outcome of the war and the duration of the sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers standing guard in Maidan Square in Kyiv on Wednesday.

item.title: Stellantis Stops Car Shipments to and From Russia
item.description: The automaker has been making delivery vans in Russia, but its chief has said production is likely to halt because of a lack of parts.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:description: The Stellantis plant in Kaluga, Russia, which is owned in partnership with Mitsubishi, in 2019.

item.title: As War Rages, a Struggle to Balance Energy Crunch and Climate Crisis
item.description: Rising oil prices and increased demand for expanded production come at a time when scientists say nations must sharply cut the use of fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer, Lisa Friedman and David Gelles
item.media:description: An oil refinery in Omsk, Russia. Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has caused the price of crude oil to skyrocket, approaching $130 per barrel this week.

item.title: Iraqi Minister Says High Oil Prices Could Speed the Shift to E.V.s
item.description: Whatever the short-term benefits for producers, the market upheaval could accelerate the transition away from oil, he says.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:description: Ihsan Abdul Jabbar, Iraq’s oil minister, in Baghdad in January. He said Middle Eastern oil producers feared high prices could reduce reliance on oil.

item.title: Major Music Companies Pause Business in Russia
item.description: The three major record conglomerates and the touring giant Live Nation are suspending operations over Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, while individual artists have canceled tour dates.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:description: Green Day canceled a planned Moscow show in May “in light of current events.”

item.title: Russian Forces Have Encircled Northern Ukraine City of Chernihiv, The Mayor Says
item.description: Ukrainian forces are battling to keep some roads open, as Russia tightens its cordon around the battered city. “We are surrounded,” the mayor said.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: After days of shelling, the city of Chernihiv has become mostly surrounded by Russian forces.

item.title: Russia’s civilian attacks
item.description: We tell you the story of a Ukrainian family that has become an international symbol of civilian death.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: Here are the latest developments in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Anton Troianovski and Shashank Bengali

item.title: BTS Performs Live in Seoul for First Time in Over 2 Years
item.description: The K-pop group returned to the stage in South Korea on Thursday, although fans were not allowed to cheer, scream or sing along because of Covid restrictions.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Fans arriving for the BTS concert at Seoul Olympic Stadium on Thursday.

item.title: ‘Free Ukraine Street’: Russian Embassies Get Pointed New Addresses
item.description: Officials in many European cities are giving streets, squares and intersections in front of Russian missions names with pro-Ukraine themes.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai, Henrik Pryser Libell and Christina Anderson
item.media:description: Installing “Ukrainian Heroes Street” signs in Lithuanian and Ukrainian on a road leading to the Russian Embassy, in the background, in Vilnius, Lithuania, on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: The heavy toll of war on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Emergency employees and volunteers carrying an injured pregnant woman from a maternity hospital damaged by Russian shelling on Wednesday in Mariupol, Ukraine.

item.title: Here are the latest developments in the war on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Anton Troianovski and Shashank Bengali

item.title: Ontario will drop its indoor mask mandate weeks after trucker protests.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat
item.media:credit: Nick Turchiaro/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: An usher at Scotiabank Arena in Toronto in December. The province of Ontario will end its universal mask mandate on March 21, officials said on Wednesday.

item.title: What a Power Cutoff Could Mean for Chernobyl’s Nuclear Waste
item.description: With no working reactors, there is no risk of a meltdown. But the ruins from the 1986 disaster still pose considerable dangers.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: The safe confinement covering, built to confine radioactive material at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant’s No. 4 reactor, in 2021.

item.title: Guatemalan Women Face Up to 10 Years in Prison Under New Abortion Law
item.description: The measure, which is expected to be signed into law by Guatemala’s conservative president within weeks, would impose the harshest punishments for abortion of almost any country in Latin America.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff, Oscar Lopez and Jody García
item.media:description: President Alejandro Giammattei speaking in Guatemala City on Wednesday.

item.title: Evgeny Maslin, Russian General Who Secured Nuclear Arsenal, Dies at 84
item.description: He persuaded Ukraine and other post-Soviet states to give up their weapons, then worked with the U.S. to safeguard and dismantle thousands of them.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: Gen. Evgeny Maslin in an undated photo. On his watch, Russia, Ukraine and the United States worked together to reduce the looming threat to global security posed by nuclear arms.

item.title: Damaged Chernobyl Nuclear Plant, Occupied by Russia, Loses Outside Power
item.description: The site of the worst nuclear accident in history, where a yearslong cleanup is underway, is now dependent on power from diesel generators and backup supplies.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Henry Fountain
item.media:description: A worker inside the safe confinement covering over the No. 4 reactor at Chernobyl in 2021.

item.title: Russia Strikes Ukraine’s Cities and Accuses U.S. of “Economic War”
item.description: Misery deepened in Ukraine, where millions of people were caught in besieged cities, and in Russia, where the West’s economic sanctions were biting hard.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: Outside a maternity hospital in Mariupol, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Poland’s Fraught Offer: Fighter Jets for Ukraine, but Only Through U.S. Hands
item.description: Neither Poland nor the United States wants to make itself — or NATO — a target of Russia. And providing MIG fighters might cross over Putin’s invisible line.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: A MIG-29 fighter jet in Vasylkiv, Ukraine in 2016. Ukrainian pilots are trained to fly the aging Russian aircraft.

item.title: Subtle Shifts Raise Hopes for a Cease-fire in Ukraine
item.description: Both Russia and Ukraine appear to have softened their stance, with the Kremlin signaling a retreat on regime change and Kyiv expressing flexibility on NATO membership. But the two sides remain far apart.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Patrick Kingsley and Michael Crowley
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin meeting with members of the Security Council via a video link last week. The Kremlin has signaled it is no longer demanding regime change in Ukraine.

item.title: Israel’s President Visits Turkey in Sign of Thawing Relations
item.description: In their highest-level meeting in 14 years, Israel and Turkey sought to rekindle an alliance after years of turbulence.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Safak Timur
item.media:description: President Isaac Herzog of Israel at a news conference with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey on Wednesday in Ankara.

item.title: Cluster Munitions and ‘Vacuum Bombs’: Russian Invasion Revives an Old Debate
item.description: Diplomats and talking heads have repeated longstanding fictions about battlefield weapons that critics argue are too cruel or too indiscriminate for use in warfare.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A residential street on Tuesday in Tenovka, Ukraine, where several homes were leveled.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Indiscriminate Attacks in Mariupol
item.description: Russia was more isolated after sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: A burned vehicle outside the maternity hospital in Mariupol on Wednesday.

item.title: Most of This Year’s New Virus Cases Were in the Americas, W.H.O. Officials Say
item.description: Countries in the region should keep public health measures in place, W.H.O. officials warned.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Politi
item.media:description: A cemetery worker placed flowers in November on the graves of people who died from Covid-19 in San Salvador, El Salvador.

item.title: Twitter Bot Highlights Gender Pay Gap One Company at a Time
item.description: Britain requires companies with 250 or more employees to report gender pay gap data. On International Women’s Day, one couple used it to raise awareness about lingering discrepancies.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: Francesca Lawson said that she and Ali Fensome created a Twitter bot, @PayGapApp, “to hold these companies to account for their role in perpetuating inequalities.”

item.title: ‘I Must Save My Mom’: The Women Returning to Ukraine
item.description: As millions seek to escape Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, 200,000 people have gone the other way, toward the fighting. Many are women, risking the dangers of war to rescue relatives or defend their homes.
item.dc:creator: Emily Rhyne, Simon Ostrovsky and Ben Laffin
item.media:credit: Emily Rhyne / The New York Times

item.title: After a Week of Siege, Bloodied Mariupol Plans Mass Graves
item.description: Under a relentless Russian barrage, there is no heat or electricity, and people are boiling snow for water. A 6-year-old died of dehydration, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Emergency employees and volunteers carrying an injured pregnant woman from a maternity hospital damaged by Russian shelling on Wednesday in Mariupol, Ukraine.

item.title: Scotland Apologizes for History of Witchcraft Persecution
item.description: Nicola Sturgeon, the first minister of Scotland, apologized on behalf of the government for the killing and vilification of thousands of people accused of witchcraft between the 16th and 18th centuries.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:description: Nicola Sturgeon, Scotland’s first minister, is the first Scottish leader to formally apologize for the persecution of people accused of witchcraft in the country centuries ago.

item.title: Biden Restores California’s Power to Set Stringent Tailpipe Rules
item.description: The state is expected to write strict auto pollution standards designed to significantly speed the transition to electric vehicles and influence new federal rules.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:description: Traffic around the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge. Twelve other states are following California’s mandate to sell only zero-emissions vehicles after 2035.

item.title: Austria Abandons Sweeping Vaccine Mandate, Citing Milder Omicron Cases
item.description: Despite high caseloads, the number of Covid patients in intensive-care-unit beds remains steady, prompting the country to rethink its approach, at least for now.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: A vaccination center in Vienna last month. Austria had been the only European country with a general vaccine mandate that extended to all adults

item.title: With Humor, and a Nod to History, Johnson and Zelensky Find a Rapport
item.description: Forging an alliance with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine was a natural for Boris Johnson, Britain’s prime minister. The two share a sense of the moment.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine addressed British lawmakers on Tuesday.

item.title: Videos: Mariupol Hospital Maternity Ward Hit by Devastating Strike
item.description: Footage from the hospital verified by The New York Times showed several wounded people being evacuated. The extent of the casualties was not immediately clear.
item.dc:creator: Ainara Tiefenthäler, Evan Hill, Dmitriy Khavin, Masha Froliak and Haley Willis

item.title: No Ikea Shelves, No Levis: The Retailers Pulling Out of Russia
item.description: Since the invasion of Ukraine began, the increasing financial and reputational risks of doing business in Russia are leading Western brands to halt operations.
item.dc:creator: Sapna Maheshwari and Vanessa Friedman
item.media:description: Stanley Black & Decker announced that it would close its business in Russia.

item.title: Benjamin Netanyahu Tests Positive For Coronavirus
item.description: Benjamin Netanyahu, the former prime minister of Israel, who is 72 and has gotten four Covid shots, “feels well,” according to a party spokesman.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel during a ceremony to honor medical teams dealing with the pandemic in Jerusalem last summer.

item.title: How Redlining Contributed to Air Pollution Across America
item.description: A new study shows how redlining, a Depression-era housing policy, contributed to inequalities that persist decades later in U.S. cities.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Nadja Popovich
item.media:credit: Source: Environmental Science & Technology Letters | By The New York Times
